conclusion: Problem involves an ideal transformer with resistances on the secondary side, an ammeter reading 1.4 A on the primary side, and a voltmeter reading 10 V on the secondary side.
Need to find the turns ratio n1:n2 of the transformer.
Primary side has an ammeter connected in series, secondary side has three resistors connected, voltmeter measures voltage across R3.
In an ideal transformer, power in the primary equals power in the secondary, voltage and current transform according to the turns ratio.
Basic transformer equations: Voltage ratio V1/V2 = n1/n2, Current ratio I1/I2 = n2/n1.
V1 is primary voltage, V2 is secondary voltage, I1 is primary current, I2 is secondary current, n1 is primary turns, n2 is secondary turns.
Voltmeter reading is 10 V across R3, ammeter reading is 1.4 A on the primary side.
Need to relate known quantities to the turns ratio.
Secondary side has three resistors R1, R2, R3 each with 50 Ω, voltmeter measures voltage across R3.
R1 is in series with R2, and R3 is in parallel with R2.
R1 is connected across secondary terminals, R2 in series with R1, R3 in parallel with R2, voltmeter across R3.
R1 is connected from the top of n2 to the junction of R2 and R3, R2 and R3 are in parallel connected to ground, voltmeter across R3.
R2 and R3 are in parallel, R1 is in series with this parallel combination.
Calculate equivalent resistance of R2 and R3 in parallel: R23 = 25 Ω.
